docs.title: I. Problem: module's path
docs.text:
• Common: We want to use a different root/source to import modules (modules here are just other python files).
  • Some specific cases:
    • Having 2 folders with the same name (in different levels in the file tree). We want to import from the subfolder only.
    • The module we want to import has a long path.

docs.title: 4. Solve it using a .pth file
docs.text:
Info

This is why I decide to write this post

Bash
cd venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages
touch any_name.pth
vim any_name.pth

Press I to switch to the insert mode, and add the path you want to be the source into this file (any_name.pth).

Press Esc+:wq+Enter to save and quit.

That's it, problem solved.

docs.title: Python venv things
docs.text:
Read this on Nguyen Khang's blog

venv

Virtual environment

docs.title: 1. Creating a new venv
docs.text:
cd to the project folder and run this:

Bash
python3 -m venv venvname

or this (you will have to run pip install virtualenv first if you have not installed it yet)

Bash
virtualenv venvname

docs.title: 2. Activating a venv
docs.text:
Bash
. venvname/bin/activate

or

Bash
source venvname/bin/activate

docs.title: 3. Deactivating an active venv
docs.text:
Bash
cd venvname/bin/
$source deactivate

docs.title: II. Venv for projects
docs.text: We could create a venv for multiple projects with the help of conda/miniforge:

docs.title: 1. list all conda discoverable environments
docs.text:
Bash
conda info --envs

If you're using VSCode or Jupyter Notebook, you could see a list of available environments like this:

docs.title: 2. Creating a new venv
docs.text:
Bash
conda create -n venvname python=x.y.z

x.y.z: python version, you could see a list of available python versions by using:

Bash
conda search "^python$"

docs.title: 3. Activating a venv
docs.text:
Bash
conda activate venvname

docs.title: 4. Install a new package
5. Deactivating an active venv
docs.text:
Bash
conda deactivate

docs.title: 6. Deleting a venv
docs.text:
Bash
conda remove -n venvname --all

docs.title: A note
docs.text:
Note

Note that we could use venv for multiple projects like the way we set up in "I. venv for a project", and this is not smart because we have to remember venv's path, the venv will also not be included in VSCode or Jupyter Notebook's environment list.

docs.title: 1. Add (base) to PATH
docs.text:
How to have a (base) before a command line like this?

  1. After installation: cd to the bin folder, for example:
Bash
cd /opt/homebrew/Caskroom/miniforge/base/bin
  1. Run init:
Bash
./conda init zsh

Exit and reopen the terminal.

docs.title: 2. Advanced for Mac users
docs.text:
./conda init zsh will automatically change the file ~/.zshrc, and help set the PATH environment variable for you.

You could check the file .zshrc before and after by using these commands:

Bash
cd ~
cat .zshrc
